Common Issues

Why People Leave Mint Mobile

Large Upfront Payments

Mint Mobile requires you to pay for 3, 6, or 12 months upfront to get advertised pricing. Their $15/month rate requires a full year payment of $180 at once.

Price Jumps After Intro

The heavily-advertised $15/month intro pricing doubles to $30/month after your first 3-month period, surprising many customers.

Weaker Rural Coverage

T-Mobile's network still lags behind AT&T in rural areas. If you travel or live outside major cities, you may experience coverage gaps.

No True Month-to-Month

Unlike truly flexible carriers, Mint Mobile doesn't offer genuine month-to-month billing - you must commit to at least 3 months minimum.

FAQ

Switching from Mint Mobile

Common questions about making the switch

Yes, you can switch anytime, but you won't get a refund for unused months. This is one reason many people prefer month-to-month carriers like Vouch Mobile - you only pay for what you use and can leave whenever you want.

Common reasons include: frustration with upfront payments, price increases after the intro period, T-Mobile's weaker rural coverage, and wanting more flexibility. Vouch Mobile addresses all these issues with true month-to-month billing on AT&T's superior rural network.

Mint Mobile phones are typically unlocked. Most modern smartphones work on all major networks. If switching to an AT&T-based carrier like Vouch Mobile, verify your phone supports AT&T's bands - most iPhones and Samsung Galaxy phones from 2019 onwards will work.

In rural and suburban areas, yes. Vouch Mobile uses AT&T's network, which has significantly better coverage outside major cities compared to T-Mobile (Mint's network). In urban areas, both networks perform similarly.

Get your Mint Mobile account number and transfer PIN from the Mint Mobile app or website. Provide these to your new carrier when signing up. Don't cancel Mint Mobile first - the port will automatically close your account. The transfer usually completes within minutes.
